description: In the 10th and 11th centuries, a tradition of painting ceramics in thick, colored slips (watered-down clay) became common practice in central and eastern Iran. These vessels were typically decorated with simple calligraphic lines, often containing blessings or pious insights, not unlike fortune cookie messages. Here the text reads, "[Generosity] is a disposition of the dwellers of Paradise . . . regret."
title: Bowl with Calligraphic Design
